Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: An Integrative Approach To Examining Migration, Community Interaction And Social Diversity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Migrations, past and present, fundamentally influence human interaction, community building, and social evolution. Large scale population movement is particularly pertinent to today's globally mobile society as the effects of climate-driven migrations continue to gain precedence in international dialogues. While anthropologists have long been interested in relationships between episodes of migration and large social transformations, few have considered the diversity of ways the actions and lives of individual agents shape these broad social movements. How do diverse migrants differentially respond to their new social and political environments, and how do their responses in turn shape new social and political transformations? Archaeology is particularly well placed to provide insight because it can contextualize the long-term effects of increasing human mobility and population interaction today in the study of prehistoric migrations spanning over hundreds or even thousands of years.

Using innovative biogeochemical analyses, this project addresses the long-term social transformations triggered by the actions of diverse individuals living within the prehistoric south central Andes. The research will be conducted at the site of Omo M10 in the Moquegua Valley of southern Peru. Omo M10 was at the center of a system of colonies established by the early expansive Tiwanaku (AD 700-1050) state and marks a unique region of interaction between contemporaneous Tiwanaku, Wari, and coastal polities. This interdisciplinary research will use bioarchaeological (sex and age at death estimates, paleopathology, cranial modification practices, diet, and funerary rituals) and biogeochemical (isotopic analyses) evidence to reconstruct the residential mobility and community affiliations of several migrant groups interred at Omo M10. The isotopic analysis of multiple dental and skeletal elements from each of 152 individuals will allow this project to reconstruct the residential mobility of these individuals throughout their lives. This fine-grained temporal control is inaccessible through traditional lines of archaeological evidence. The researchers will result in the training of a group of Peruvian and American undergraduate university students in the interdisciplinary biogeochemical and osteological methods employed, promoting future international collaborations and contributing to the participation of underrepresented groups in science. This project will significantly alter current understandings of early South American complex polities. Further, the innovative interdisciplinary approach employed provides future researchers with the tools necessary to identify the significance of individual actors in large scale and long-term social transformations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Allisen Dahlstedt has completed research for her dissertation “An Integrative Approach To Examining Migration, Community Interaction, and Social Diversity” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During the funding period, she examined the role of migration in community building and social integration at the margins of the expansive pre-Hispanic Tiwanaku state in the southern Andes. Migration research in contemporary societies demonstrates the importance of ongoing interaction between immigrants, their homeland communities, and other local groups in maintaining and developing new social, political, and cultural affiliations. An immigrant’s ongoing interaction network is therefore as significant to their community identity as their place of origin. Investigating migration in the past provides a deep-time perspective which we can use to better understand long-term human responses to migration and increasing social diversity.

This project used isotopic analysis of archaeological human remains to reconstruct the immigration of Tiwanaku-affiliated individuals into the Moquegua Valley of Peru during the Middle Horizon (ca. AD 500-1100). Dahlstedt investigated how these isotopic indicators of residential mobility correspond with or crosscut individual characteristics including sex and age at death, as well as social identities indicated by spatial burial patterns and cranial modification forms. Three important aspects of migration are addressed: (1) the proportion of the community composed of first-generation immigrants (scale) and their origins, (2) the demographics of migrants and frequency with which they travel between homeland and other communities, and (3) the impact of these migration processes on community affiliations with Tiwanaku and neighboring polities.

The results of this project are significant for archaeological approaches to human migration and Andean archaeology. First, this study shows the utility of biogeochemical data in identifying first-generation immigrants in archaeological contexts, as well as individuals who frequently moved between different regions. Exploring these data through social migration theory demonstrates how interaction spheres created and maintained through migration influenced community building in ancient societies. At a regional level, this study provides a nuanced perspective of Tiwanaku state expansion during the Middle Horizon in the Andes. The results demonstrate that the Tiwanaku community at Omo M10 in the Moquegua Valley was composed of diverse multi-generational immigrants that maintained ongoing, though varied, interactions with homeland and neighboring communities. Finally, this study’s focus on changes in individuals’ behaviors and social identities across their lifetimes serves as an important complement to previous regional bioarchaeological investigations of broader community dynamics and genetic relationships.  

This research has four primary broader impacts. First, the multiple lines of isotopic and osteological context data generated and synthesized by this project have been presented at national and international conferences and are currently in preparation for publication in peer-reviewed journals, ensuring data access for current and future scholars. Project results have been made available to the broader community through public presentations at Arizona State University and at the Museo Contisuyo in Moquegua, Peru. Second, the project enhanced the international research and educational partnership between Arizona State University, the Museo Contisuyo in Moquegua Peru, and the University of California San Diego. Dahlstedt additionally aided in the curation of human remains and mortuary artifacts at the Museo Contisuyo during her initial data collection, improving the longevity of these collections.

Third, during the course of this research, Dahlstedt trained 27 undergraduate students to prepare and analyze archaeological samples for isotopic analyses in the Archaeological Chemistry Laboratory. These students come from diverse educational and cultural backgrounds and the majority are women, with many now pursing advanced degrees and contributing to the creation of a more diverse scientific community. Finally, this project impacts society today by informing long-term human responses to migration and increasing social diversity.
